metadata.titleEn: Surface PM2.5 concentrations in Tibetan Plateau (2020)
metadata.description: The surface PM2.5 concentration data of Tibet Plateau is named by date (YYYYMMDD). Each NC file contains one day's data, which is composed of PM2.5 concentration, longitude, latitude, and time information of the area (the corresponding variables in the data are named with PM2.5, lon, lat, time). The data inversion relies on the reanalysis data MERRA-2 released by NASA and the AOD product of Multi-angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer (MISR). MERRA-2 is mainly based on NASA GMAO Earth system model version 5 (GEOS 5). The algorithm is able to assimilate all the in-situ and re- motely-sensed atmospheric data. This dataset mainly focuses on the aerosol field of MERRA-2. This is the first multi-decadal reanalysis within which meteorological and aerosol observations are jointly assimilated into a global assimilation system. MISR views Earth with cameras pointed in 9 different directions， which can help us know the amount of sunlight that is scattered in different directions under natural conditions. The main data products used in this data algorithm are MERRA-2 aerosol analysis product (M2T1NXAER) and MISR Level 3 version 4 global aerosol products (MIL3DAEN_4). Firstly, the ratio of PM2.5 to AOD in each grid was calculated by using the aerosol information provided by MERRA-2. Second, the PM2.5 concentration of the grid was calculated by multiplying the AOD of MISR by the ratio. The mean prediction error of PM2.5 concentration obtained by this method is within 20 μg/m3. The corresponding PM2.5 products can be used for the assessment of particulate pollution in the Tibet Plateau.

background: Knowledge of spatiotemporal distribution of fine particulate matter with aerodynamic diameter of 2.5μm or less (PM2.5) is highly needed since PM2.5 particles can enter the lungs, cause respiratory diseases, increase risk of cardiovascular and even lung cancer. Establishment of ground monitoring network is the ideal way to accurately measure ground-level PM2.5 concentration, which is exactly why thousands of ground sites have been deployed in the United States and Western Europe. However, sparse geographic coverage of the network is not dense enough for monitoring PM2.5 at spatial scales of a few kilometers and maintaining such networks are very costly. In addition, most developing nations have few or no surface PM2.5 measurements, therefore, alternative methods are highly required to monitor PM2.5. It has been proved that satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD), the column-integrated aerosol extinction, is a good surrogate for PM2.5.
research objective: Here, to mitigate non-random sampling deficiency in MODIS AOD product for surface-level PM2.5 estimates, we have combined Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model, for the first time, to produce more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products and thereafter PM2.5 estimates.
challenges: PM2.5 estimates solely based on the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) AOD products may lead to a substantial bias because of non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions. Furthermore, this non-random sampling issue can be exacerbated in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are likely misclassified into clouds.
methods: Ground-based AOD measurements from Sun-photometers (Cimel Electronique, CE-318) were collected at 9 stations as a part of CARSNET or AERONET in NCP (Fig. 1). To validate filling AOD products, we choose the Level 1.5 AOD measurements at Beijing RADI site (not used in the BME method) as the independent dataset in the validation. The MODIS AOD data are gridded into 10 km by 10 km by using the nearest-neighbor interpolation method. First, the linear regression analysis is used to build the relationship between Terra and Aqua AODs for each grid if both are available. Second, missing Terra (Aqua) AOD is filled by using the linear-fit equation(1) with Aqua (Terra) AOD if available. Based on these quality-controlled hourly PM2.5 data, we calculate daily average PM2.5 concentrations if there are 20 hourly measurements each day. Here we use linear mixed-effects model (LME) to estimate PM2.5 concentrations from AOD products as a result of its simplicity and robustness (LME) (Lee et al., 2011). Daily mean AODs at AERONET and CARSNET stations are calculated and taken as the hard data for the BME algorithm. For pixels with satellite AODs are available, the Gaussian distribution probability soft data follows the normal distribution− μσ N(AOD , )combine 2 . In spatiotemporal geo-statistics, the spatiotemporal covariance is a function of distance in space and time (Fig. 3). For comparison, two BME AOD products are derived, i.e., BME-S AOD derived with only soft data and BME-SH AOD derived with satellite and sunphotometer AOD as soft and hard data, respectively.
dataset: Ground-based AOD measurements from Sun-photometers (Cimel Electronique, CE-318) were collected at 9 stations as a part of CARSNET or AERONET in NCP (Fig. 1). The latest Version 3 cloud-screened and quality assured AOD data (Level 2.0) are used for calculating daily mean AOD. Hourly PM2.5 concentrations from September 2014 to February 2015 at 264 monitors (Fig. 1) are obtained from the website of the China Environmental Monitoring Center (CEMC) (http://106.37.208.233:20035/).
findings: Relative to the standard MODIS AOD product, the integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD through BME showed increases in both spatiotemporal completeness (up to 96%) and the quality. The resultant monthly PM2.5 estimates from the BME-LME had a bias of 3.5 μgm −3 and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 5.5μgm −3, showing substantial improvement over PM2.5 estimations from original MODIS AOD product (a bias of 84.1 and a RMSE of 112.1μgm −3). Merging sunphotometer and satellite AOD observations with BME-LME is a prospective method to simultaneously improve AOD and PM2.5 estimates.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that combines satellite imagery with ground-based measurements to estimate PM2.5 concentrations?
Example.Answer: One example is the combination of MODIS AOD products with ground-based AOD measurements from Sun-photometers, integrating these data using the Bayesian maximum entropy method alongside the Linear Mixed-Effects model to estimate PM2.5 concentrations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data for PM2.5 estimation in heavily polluted regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge includes the non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions, which can be exacerbated in polluted areas where heavy aerosol loadings are often misclassified as clouds, leading to substantial biases in PM2.5 estimates.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that has been used to validate satellite-based PM2.5 estimates?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes ground-based AOD measurements collected from Sun-photometers at 9 stations as part of CARSNET or AERONET in the North China Plain, which are used as independent data for validation of the filling AOD products derived from satellite data.

Feature Specification.Answer: assimilation of in-situ and remote sensing atmospheric data, MERRA-2 aerosol fields, PM2.5 to AOD ratio, MISR AOD

Feature Specification.Answer: non-random AOD sampling deficiencies, swap-gap regions, substantial bias in PM2.5 estimates

Definition.Question: What does 'Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method' mean in the context of improving PM2.5 estimates?
Definition.Answer: In the context of improving PM2.5 estimates, the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method refers to a statistical approach that combines both soft data (e.g., satellite-derived AOD) and hard data (e.g., ground-based AOD measurements) to produce more complete and precise estimations. It utilizes spatiotemporal covariances to address deficiencies like non-random AOD sampling, particularly in conditions such as clouds or swap-gap regions, thereby improving the quality of PM2.5 estimates.

Definition.Question: What is meant by the 'Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model' in estimating PM2.5 concentrations?
Definition.Answer: The Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model, in estimating PM2.5 concentrations, is a statistical model that is used for its simplicity and robustness. It incorporates both fixed and random effects to account for variability within data, allowing for more accurate estimations of PM2.5 concentrations from aerosol optical depth (AOD) products. It is particularly useful in handling complex datasets where both spatial and temporal variations need to be captured.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using NASA's GEOS 5 and MODIS AOD products compare in terms of addressing the non-random sampling deficiency for PM2.5 estimation?
Comparison.Answer: NASA's GEOS 5 uses a global assimilation system that integrates in-situ and remote sensing atmospheric data, addressing non-random sampling deficiencies by using MERRA-2 aerosol information and MISR AOD for PM2.5 estimation. MODIS AOD products, on the other hand, encounter challenges with non-random sampling, particularly in cloudy conditions, which can lead to biases. The integration with sunphotometer AOD using Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) and Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models helps to mitigate these biases, improving spatiotemporal completeness and accuracy.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced by ground-based networks and satellite-based methods in monitoring PM2.5 concentrations?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based networks provide accurate PM2.5 measurements but face challenges such as sparse geographic coverage and high maintenance costs, especially in developing regions. Satellite-based methods, like those using MODIS AOD, face challenges with non-random sampling deficiencies, particularly in cloudy or heavily polluted regions where aerosols may be misclassified as clouds. Satellite methods require innovative approaches, such as the BME-LME model, to improve data completeness and accuracy.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do datasets derived from MERRA-2 aerosol products and MODIS AOD differ in their application to PM2.5 concentration estimation?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets derived from MERRA-2 aerosol products are used in conjunction with MISR AOD to calculate PM2.5 concentrations, focusing on the aerosol and meteorological data assimilation for accuracy. MODIS AOD datasets, while useful for PM2.5 estimation, may lead to biases due to non-random sampling issues, particularly under certain atmospheric conditions. The use of BME and LME models with MODIS AOD enhances accuracy by integrating sunphotometer data, leading to more complete and precise PM2.5 estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How can satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data be effectively utilized to improve estimates of PM2.5 concentrations in areas with sparse ground monitoring networks?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite-based AOD, such as from MODIS, can be used as a surrogate for PM2.5 by addressing non-random sampling deficiencies. Techniques like Bayesian Maximum Entropy (BME) combined with Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models can produce more complete and precise AOD products, improving PM2.5 estimates by integrating both satellite and ground-based AOD measurements.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges in using satellite-derived AOD for estimating PM2.5 levels in regions with high pollution or cloud cover, and how can these challenges be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include non-random AOD sampling deficiencies due to cloud cover and misclassification of heavy aerosol loadings as clouds. These can be mitigated by using methods like BME, which leverages both soft data from satellites and hard data from sunphotometer AOD measurements to enhance the completeness and accuracy of the AOD products, leading to better PM2.5 estimates.

Interpretation.Question: What role do ground-based AOD measurements play in validating and enhancing satellite-derived PM2.5 estimates, and how might these measurements be integrated into satellite data processing frameworks?
Interpretation.Answer: Ground-based AOD measurements provide critical validation and enhancement for satellite-derived PM2.5 estimates. They can be integrated into satellite data processing frameworks by serving as hard data inputs in models like BME, which combine these measurements with satellite-derived soft data to improve the spatiotemporal completeness and accuracy of the resultant AOD and PM2.5 estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in obtaining precise PM2.5 estimates using satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data, especially in regions with heavy aerosol loadings?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: PM2.5 estimates based on satellite AOD data may experience substantial bias due to non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and regions with heavy aerosol loadings, where aerosols are likely misclassified into clouds.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for alternative methods to monitor PM2.5 levels in developing nations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Developing nations often have few or no surface PM2.5 measurements due to sparse geographic coverage and the high cost of maintaining ground monitoring networks, necessitating alternative methods to monitor PM2.5 levels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the improvement in spatiotemporal completeness and quality of PM2.5 estimates when integrating satellite and sunphotometer AOD observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD through the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method increases spatiotemporal completeness and quality, reducing bias and root mean square error (RMSE) in PM2.5 estimates compared to using only satellite AOD data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the assimilation of meteorological and aerosol observations into a global assimilation system affect the prediction of PM2.5 concentrations in regions with sparse ground monitoring networks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The assimilation of meteorological and aerosol observations into a global assimilation system, like MERRA-2, allows for the generation of more accurate PM2.5 concentration estimates in regions with sparse ground monitoring networks, such as the Tibetan Plateau. This method helps to overcome the limitations of sparse ground data by using comprehensive atmospheric models and remote sensing data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible consequences of using non-random AOD sampling in cloudy conditions on PM2.5 estimates, and how might integrating different data sources mitigate these issues?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Non-random AOD sampling in cloudy conditions can lead to substantial biases in PM2.5 estimates, particularly in polluted regions. Integrating different data sources, such as satellite and sunphotometer AOD observations through methods like BME-LME, can mitigate these issues by improving the spatiotemporal completeness and quality of the AOD products, thereby enhancing the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of integrating Bayesian maximum entropy with a linear mixed-effects model in estimating PM2.5 concentrations from satellite data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to produce more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products and thereafter PM2.5 estimates, mitigating non-random sampling deficiency in MODIS AOD product for surface-level PM2.5 estimates.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of using the MERRA-2 aerosol analysis product and MISR AOD data to estimate PM2.5 concentrations in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefit is to provide a reference for assessing particulate matter pollution in the Tibetan Plateau by calculating PM2.5 concentrations with an average prediction error within 20 micrograms per cubic meter, utilizing a novel assimilation of meteorological and aerosol observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to integrate aerosol optical depth (AOD) data from different satellite sources for PM2.5 estimation in regions with sparse ground monitoring networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To integrate aerosol optical depth (AOD) data from different satellite sources, a Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method combined with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model is used. This approach addresses non-random sampling deficiencies in MODIS AOD products by filling missing AOD data and creating more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products, which are then used to estimate PM2.5 concentrations.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the integration of satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) with ground-based measurements for PM2.5 estimation?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of satellite-based AOD, such as MODIS, with ground-based measurements from sun-photometers has been enabled by advancements in Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) methods and Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models, which help produce more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products.

Enablement.Question: How do ground-based AOD measurements enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates derived from satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: Ground-based AOD measurements from sun-photometers are used as hard data in the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) algorithm, which, when combined with satellite AOD data, significantly improves the spatiotemporal completeness and accuracy of PM2.5 estimates.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for successfully merging sun-photometer and satellite AOD observations to improve PM2.5 estimates?
Enablement.Answer: Successfully merging sun-photometer and satellite AOD observations requires the availability of quality-controlled, cloud-screened AOD data, the capability to handle non-random sampling deficiencies, and the use of robust statistical models like BME-LME to improve the spatiotemporal completeness and reduce biases and errors in PM2.5 estimates.

Expectation.Question: Why might satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) estimates lead to a substantial bias in PM2.5 estimations under certain conditions?
Expectation.Answer: PM2.5 estimates solely based on satellite AOD products like MODIS may lead to a substantial bias due to non-random AOD sampling deficiencies in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions. This issue is exacerbated in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are likely misclassified into clouds.

Expectation.Question: Why are alternative methods required for monitoring PM2.5 in developing nations?
Expectation.Answer: Developing nations often have few or no surface PM2.5 measurements due to the sparse geographic coverage of ground monitoring networks and the high costs associated with maintaining these networks. Therefore, alternative methods like satellite-based AOD are highly required to monitor PM2.5.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges in integrating satellite and ground-based data for PM2.5 estimation, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in integrating satellite and ground-based data for PM2.5 estimation include non-random AOD sampling deficiency due to cloudy conditions and misclassification of heavy aerosol loadings as clouds. These issues can lead to substantial biases. To address these challenges, methods such as combining Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model have been developed to produce more complete and precise AOD products, thereby improving PM2.5 estimates by merging satellite data with sun-photometer measurements.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) can be a reliable surrogate for PM2.5 concentrations.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite-based AOD, the column-integrated aerosol extinction, is considered a good surrogate for PM2.5 because it allows for the estimation of PM2.5 concentrations where ground measurements are sparse or unavailable. The methodology involves calculating the ratio of PM2.5 to AOD from aerosol data products like MERRA-2 and then applying this ratio to AOD data from MISR to estimate PM2.5 concentrations.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand the challenges faced in using MODIS AOD products for PM2.5 estimates.
Assertion.Answer: MODIS AOD products face challenges due to non-random AOD sampling deficiencies in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions. This issue is further exacerbated in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are often misclassified as clouds, leading to substantial biases in PM2.5 estimates.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure why establishing ground monitoring networks for PM2.5 is considered ideal but also problematic.
Assertion.Answer: Ground monitoring networks are ideal because they provide accurate measurements of ground-level PM2.5 concentrations. However, they are problematic due to the sparse geographic coverage, which is insufficient for monitoring PM2.5 at fine spatial scales, and because maintaining such networks is very costly, particularly in developing nations that have few or no surface PM2.5 measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a method to combine satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data with ground-based measurements to estimate PM2.5 concentrations in regions with sparse monitoring networks.
Request/Directive.Answer: A method to combine satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data with ground-based measurements involves using the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method paired with a Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model. This approach aims to create spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products to estimate PM2.5 levels. Ground-based AOD measurements from Sun-photometers are collected at various stations, and the MODIS AOD data is gridded using nearest-neighbor interpolation. The linear regression analysis builds the relationship between Terra and Aqua AODs, filling missing data. This integration improves the completeness and quality of PM2.5 estimates compared to using satellite data alone.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with estimating PM2.5 concentrations using MODIS AOD data and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges associated with estimating PM2.5 concentrations using MODIS AOD data include non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions, leading to substantial bias. This issue is worsened in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are often misclassified as clouds. A potential solution is the integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD data through the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method, which increases spatiotemporal completeness and quality. The resultant PM2.5 estimates show a significant reduction in bias and root mean square error compared to estimates based solely on standard MODIS AOD products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe a potential dataset that can be used to validate spatiotemporal PM2.5 estimates derived from satellite data.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for validating spatiotemporal PM2.5 estimates derived from satellite data includes ground-based AOD measurements collected from Sun-photometers, which are part of networks like CARSNET or AERONET. These measurements are complemented by the latest Version 3 cloud-screened and quality assured AOD data (Level 2.0) for calculating daily mean AOD. Additionally, hourly PM2.5 concentrations from a network of monitors, such as those available from the China Environmental Monitoring Center (CEMC), can serve as an independent dataset for validation purposes.
